titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Time Inc. Time Research Center Files
1923-1994
MS 3009-RG 13
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Holly Deakyne, Samantha Brown
titlestmt.sponsor: The processing of the Time Inc. Records was made possible by a generous grant from the Henry Luce Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2018-02-26T09:34-0500

did.unittitle: Time Inc. Time Research Center Files
did.abstract: The Time Research Center Files contain research materials collected by Time Inc. reporters, researchers, and library staff in the main areas of Bio Files, Presidents Files, and Subject Files. Many of the files originally belonged to a Time Inc. reference library known throughout the years as The Morgue, The Bureau of Editorial Reference, and The Editorial Reference Library. Currently the only series available is Series II. Presidents Files.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The files from the Time Research Center originally belonged to a Time Inc. library known throughout the years as The Morgue, The Bureau of Editorial Reference, and The Editorial Reference Library. It seems like the library existed longest as The Editorial Reference Library, and most staff referred to it as “Edit Ref”. The library maintained research materials that reporters and researchers from all magazines used when writing articles. Editorial Services managed the library along with the Picture Collection (later called the Life Picture Collection), Archives (beginning in the mid-1990s), the Index Department (closed in 1994 or 1995), and the Photo Lab.

The files were built over the years from the various magazines' Carbon Files. A Carbon File was created by a reporter for every article that ran in a Time Inc. magazine, comprising all the collected research, and retained by that magazine for around 14 months before being turned over to the Editorial Reference Library. There the contents were distributed into the Bio, Subject or Company Files. Library staff also added additional clippings to the files. The bulk of the Company Files were sent to an offsite storage facility and lost in a series of storage facility arsons in the mid-1990s.

Time Warner closed The Editorial Reference Library in 2001 after the AOL merger failure. At this time, staff culled the files and sent some to the smaller libraries funded by individual magazines. Business and finance subjects went to the Business Information Research Center, a library used by Money and Fortune, and Fortune still maintains these files. Entertainment industry subjects went to the People Research Center, and these files later were acquired by the LAC Group. Files not culled or sent to another library became property of the newly created Time Research Center housed in offsite storage.
Bill Hooper, email message to Holly Deakyne, 6 July 2016.
Bill Hooper, email message to Holly Deakyne, 25 August 2016.
Bill Hooper, email message to Holly Deakyne, 15 May 2017.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The Time Inc. Time Research Center Files contain research materials used by reporters and researchers at various magazines across Time Inc. The files are in three main series of Bio Files, Presidents Files, and Subject Files with smaller series containing administrative files relating to the research files and reference books.

The majority of research and reference materials are magazine and newspaper clippings. Other types of material include telegrams and other correspondence, correspondent dispatches, transcripts of interviews and speeches, editorial outlines for articles, editorial policies, press releases, and drafts of articles.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: The record group is currently organized in one series, with additional series expected as future accruals are received and processed:

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open to qualified researchers with the exception of restricted materials. Restricted materials may include medical records and records with personally identifiable information. Restricted boxes include R27. Items with preservation issues are also listed as restricted and may be available for use upon request. These materials are in box R22.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: This collection is owned by the New-York Historical Society. Although the N-YHS owns this collection as physical property, the donor specifically retains all copyright and all other proprietary rights which may exist. The copyright law of the United States governs the making of photocopies and protects unpublished materials as well as published materials. Unpublished materials created before January 1, 1978 cannot be quoted in publication without permission of the copyright holder

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation Note
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as Time Inc. Time Research Center Files, MS 3009-RG 13, The New-York Historical Society.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials Note
relatedmaterial.p: This finding aid relates to just one record group of the Time Inc. Records. For information about the other record groups and for overall information about the archives, please see the Guide to the Time Inc. Records (MS 3009). The Henry Luce Papers (MS 3014) were acquired with the Time Inc. Records. The collection of books acquired with the records are cataloged as the Time Inc. Reference Library.

accruals.head: Accruals Note
accruals.p: Further additions to this finding aid are expected.

processinfo.head: Processing Information Note
processinfo.p: The Presidents Files were processed by Samantha Brown in 2017 and 2018. The original folders were retained although some documents were transferred to archival containers in instances of overcrowding. Brown created the inventory and other descriptive notes to produce this finding aid. The name of the series was changed to not cause confusion with official presidential files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The Presidents Files, called Presidential Files by Time Inc., contain research materials regarding United States presidents used by reporters and researchers at various magazines across Time Inc. While a wide range of materials were collected, many of the items focus on important events that the president attended, any honors the president received prior to or during their presidency, domestic and foreign policies of an administration, public appearances and statements made by the president, White House staffing decisions, the finances of the incoming president, recreational activities that the president enjoyed, and details about their family.

Materials related to a specific president and a specific subject are in files that include the president's name and a subject as part of the titles. Subjects frequently collected include administration, advisers and assistants, appointments, awards and honors, cabinet, cartoons, congress, correspondence, domestic affairs, family, finances, foreign relations, inauguration, politics, polls, press relations, recreation, speeches, travel, and welfare. Files titled "Sketches" includes general material or biographical details or essays about the president and not drawings. Duplicates of items can be found in different folders for a president if the item relates to more than one topic.

The majority of materials are magazine and newspaper clippings. Other types of material include article correction forms, telegrams, correspondent dispatches, correspondence between reporters as well as correspondence with White House press representatives, transcripts of interviews and speeches, editorial outlines for articles, editorial policies, press releases, event schedules and programs, event invite lists, lists of White House staff, campaign pamphlets, biographical overviews, drafts of articles, academic papers and articles about the president and his policies, and financial reports.
According to the storage facility used by Time Inc., one box of John F. Kennedy files spanning from "Powers and Duties" to "Quotes" was destroyed in a flood.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Based on the original schema, the materials within the Presidents Files are organized chronologically by presidential term and titled with the president's name starting with George Washington and ending with Bill Clinton. Not all presidents are represented within the files. Within each president, files are further organized alphabetically by subject with general files at the front.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The 1977-1979 folder contains correspondence related to the posthumous promotion of President George Washington to position of General of the Armies of the United States as well as correspondence related to the discovery of letters sent by President Washington to General Thomas Gage, the Commander-in-Chief of the British Armies in North America from 1763 to 1775.

did.unittitle: Hayes, Mrs. Rutherford Birchard (née Lucy Ware Webb)
Wilson, Mrs. Woodrow (née Ellen Louise Axson)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: This file contains two pieces of microfiche containing copies of an article from the New York Times from January 18, 1925 detailing a speech Coolidge gave to the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

scopecontent.p: The file labeled Eisenhower, Dwight D: Awards and Honors: 1955 does not contain materials related to Eisenhower or the awards he received during his presidency. All the materials in this file appear to be from a biographical file for Mrs. Harvey Firestone.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Folder 12, which contains materials from November 25, 1963, includes a Nielsen Television Index special report. The report focuses on the television response to the death of President Kennedy from November 22 to November 25 1963.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Folder 10, which contains materials from October 1975, includes a letter from a Time reader. The letter includes research related to theories about President Kennedy's assassination.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Folder 7, which contains materials from 1967, includes two copies of the Nix Film Analysis Report from May 18, 1967. The report examines "The Assassination of President Kennedy," a film which was recorded by Orville O. Nix during the assassination of President Kennedy.

Folder 11, which includes materials from 1965, contains correspondence and contracts related to the sale of the gun used by Lee Harvey Oswald to assassinate President Kennedy. In addition to correspondence and contracts, there is also a police report examining the gun that was used in the assassination.

did.unittitle: Kennedy, John Fitzgerald: Awards and Honors

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Included with the materials in this folder is a photograph of the Laetare Medal that was presented to President Kennedy by the University of Notre Dame on November 22, 1961.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Folder 14, which contains materials from 1964 to 1968, includes photos of doodles made by President Kennedy during meetings and discussions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Folder 13, which contains materials from 1941 through 1956, includes a signed letter from 1956. During this period, President Johnson was a United States Senator from Texas as well as the leader of the Democratic Party. The letter discusses a questionnaire that the Senator had completed for Fortune. The questionnaire that asked questions about current events and United States policies, is also included in the folder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Folder 8, which contains materials from 1941 through 1964, includes two copies of a report on the assets and liabilities of the Johnson Family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Folder 4, which contains materials from 1965, includes an inauguration program.
